Comment: Nah, it's not the same sorry. I'm an Australian who's glad Dutton lost, but I was never as concerned about him as I was about Trump. Not only is Trump significantly worse (I disagree with Dutton's policies, but at least he seems to believe in them and he respects the political process), but the only reason Trump can do so much damage is because the US political system is enabling him. It's a perfect storm - SCOTUS refused to hold him accountable, Congress has never been able to hold him accountable - the separation of powers has failed because of how deeply entrenched the US has become in partisanship.   Australia is completely different. We have a political system that doesn't shine the spotlight on a single person, but rather the party as whole. We don't directly elect our head of state, they're selected by the party, so we avoid celebrity-leader situations in which someone with zero political experience but a lot of money and fame can become the head of state. Our courts are not split by partisanship. While we still are primarily governed by two parties, our minor parties and independents hold some power, which can still cause the major parties to compromise. We achieve that largely because we have a preferential voting system.    There are so, so, SO many aspects of the Australian political system that differ from the US in a way that prevent a Trump-like situation. I'm not saying it can't happen here, because let's be honest, I never thought it would get THIS bad in the US. But we can't pretend that an LNP win (that's our conservatives) last night would have been as disastrous as a Trump presidency.
